subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... From: Lauren Bish  ... coverage ... all ... may ... as ... coverage ... they ... Just to be clear what I meant by saying that
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Lauren Bish" <developerdude@...>

> 4) To make sure that non-visable methods are properly tested, code
coverage
> tools should be used in lieu of explicitly writing tests for these
> non-visible methods or code. This results in making explicitly sure that
all
> code is actually tested (more so than writing tests that access private
> methods directly) - which is the purpose, it is more productive, and it
may
> point out unused code or logic errors missed by just assuming that because
> the test passed the code has been completely tested. Testing code is only
as
> good the measured results. Pass/fails are one type of result, code
coverage
> metrics are another - the latter more qualitative than the former - and
they
> should be used together.

Just to be clear what I meant by saying that code-coverage is more
qualitative than pass/fail tests.

While code coverage does give a quantitative measure of test coverage, and
pass/fail tests give a qualitative measure - code coverage will tell you
more about that particular quality of your testing effort than pass/fail
tests. If you don't measure this quality then you won't truly know how well
you have tested your code - you will only have an educated guess at best.

FWIW,
Lauren
